CatDescriptText: Jean Kelly, telephone receptionist, Mars and Albert I. Smith, student, Homewood, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, June 10, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that the 'Freedom Riders' should accede to Atty. Gen. Robert Kennedy's request for a 'cooling-off' period in their program to test segregation laws of certain Southern states?" Jean Kelly's answer reads: "I don't think they would gain anything by waiting."  Albert I. Smith's answer reads: "Really, I think they should continue, I don't think that the Attorney General is doing much.  Actually, I don't think that he can do too much, because he's a Democrat and Democrats, in the past, have not done too much for the people."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Jean Kelly wearing sleeveless shirt and eyeglasses, standing on sidewalk with buildings in background; Portrait of Albert I. Smith wearing gabardine suit jacket, standing in front of entryway to building
